text: Brasilia, the new capital for che country, was

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: CIAM (Congres Internationaux d’Architec-
label: Title

text: ture Moderne). The foundation of CIAM in
label: Paragraph

text: 1928 has been called the beginning of the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘academic’ phase of modern architecture: the
label: Title

text: ume certainly appeared propitious for the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of some kind of international
label: Title

text: order into the scattered and independent essays
label: Title

text: towards a new architecture whose international
label: Title

text: unity of intention and style had been demon
label: Paragraph

text: strated at the Wei®enhot exhibition of the
label: Paragraph

text: previous year.
label: Paragraph

text: The effective impetus towards the founda-
label: Paragraph

text: dion of CIAM came from Helene de Mandrot, a
label: Paragraph

text: sincere and intelligent woman who had aspira-
label: Paragraph

text: tions towards being a patroness of the arts. She
label: Paragraph

text: proposed in the first place a reunion of creative
label: Paragraph

text: spirits at her chateau at La Sarraz, Switzerland,
label: Paragraph

text: but this romantic project was turned to some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing more purposeful after consultation with
label: Paragraph

text: Sigfricd Giedion and *Le Corbusier, The pre-
label: Paragraph

text: paratory document, issued to intending dele-
label: Paragraph

text: gates, stated: ‘This first congress is convened
label: Paragraph

text: with the aim of establishing a programme of
label: Paragraph

text: action to drag architecture from the academic
label: Title

text: impasse and to place it in its proper social and
label: Paragraph

text: economic milieu. This congress should
label: Paragraph

text: determine the limits of the studies and discus-
label: Paragraph

text: sions shortly to be undertaken by further
label: Paragraph

text: congresses.” Although a distinction was thus
label: Paragraph

text: made between the preparatory congress and
label: Paragraph

text: later meetings, the date of 26, 27, and 28 June
label: Paragraph

text: 1928 at La Sarraz is remembered and recorded as
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM I, in spite of the fact that the properly
label: Paragraph

text: constituted series of congresses did not begin
label: Paragraph

text: until the following year.
label: Paragraph

text: The contents of the declaration of 28 June
label: Title

text: embodied most of the best aspirations as well as
label: Paragraph

text: the most fashionable fetishes of the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of the time. Sample statements read: ‘Ir is only
label: Paragraph

text: from the present that our architectural work
label: Paragraph

text: should be derived’, and ‘The intention that
label: Paragraph

text: brings us together is that of attaining a harmony
label: Paragraph

text: of existing elements — a harmony indispensable
label: Paragraph

text: to the present — BY PUTTING ARCHITECTURE BACK
label: Paragraph

text: ON ITS REAL PLANE, THE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL
label: Paragraph

text: PLANE; therefore architecture should be freed of
label: Paragraph

text: the sterile influence of the Academies and of
label: Paragraph

text: antiquated formulas’, and again, ‘The most
label: Paragraph

text: efficacious production is derived from ration-
label: Paragraph

text: alization and standardization.”
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Cubism. Movement in European painting in
label: Paragraph

text: the carly 20th century which developed the
label: Paragraph

text: new “way of seeing’ which Paul Cézanne had
label: Paragraph

text: already introduced around the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, whereby the representation of objects
label: Paragraph

text: is reduced to compositions of clemental forms.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cubist movement arose in Paris between
label: Paragraph

text: 1905 and tyio from parallel developments in
label: Paragraph

text: which, above all, Georges Braque and Pablo
label: Paragraph

text: Picasso played decisive roles. The essence of.
label: Paragraph

text: their experiments. which drew their formal
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration from a variety of sources including
label: Paragraph

text: African art, was the depiction of three-dimen-
label: Paragraph

text: sional space without recourse to illusionistic
label: Title

text: perspective devices. Among the most impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant characteristics of the Cubist formal lan-
label: Paragraph

text: guage
label: Title

text: simple geometric structures; sculptural repro-
label: Paragraph

text: ductions of objects in their spatial entirety, in
label: Paragraph

text: which they separated the component surfs
label: Paragraph

text: and either placed them next to one another or
label: Paragraph

text: represented then as penetrating one another by
label: Paragraph

text: transparent effects, simulation of the simulta-
label: Title

text: neous perception of the diverse aspects of an
label: Paragraph

text: object. in which no single aspect is given
label: Paragraph

text: priority. All of these techniques gave expression
label: Paragraph

text: to their principal aim: to represent not only
label: Paragraph

text: what can be seen but, above all, what is known
label: Paragraph

text: about an object.
label: Paragraph

text: The direct application of Cubism to architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture remained problematic. The project for a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Villa Cubiste’ by the sculptor Raymond Du-
label: Caption

text: champ-Villon (1912) was nothing more than a
label: Paragraph

text: conventional neo-classical house with applied
label: Paragraph

text: Cubist decoration. The situation was not
label: Paragraph

text: greatly different in the case of the Prague or
label: Paragraph

text: Czech architectural Cubist group, which co-
label: Paragraph

text: alesced after Tg11 around the magazine U'méleky
label: Paragraph

text: Mésiénik. Yet. even im their work the Cubist
label: Paragraph

text: elements were confined to ornament, or at best
label: Paragraph

text: a sculptural handling of fagades, which did nat
label: Paragraph

text: affect either the ground-plan or the ‘type’ of the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. In any case the relatively short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: episode produced bizarre architectural sculp-
label: Title

text: ture often close in spirit to contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: *Expressionism. The principal protagonists of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Deutscher Werkbund. Founded in Munich
label: Paragraph

text: on y October 1907 as an association of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: craitsmen, industrialists, teachers and
label: Paragraph

text: publicists, its aim was the ‘ennobling of German
label: Paragraph

text: work’. Its members conceived of work as
label: Paragraph

text: embracing both handiwork and industrial
label: Paragraph

text: work, which constituted the major difference
label: Paragraph

text: between the Werkbund and the English *Arts
label: Title

text: and Crafts movement, which had served as the
label: Paragraph

text: basis for the German group. The Artsand Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: embodied the protestations of men such as
label: Paragraph

text: William *Morris against the flood of flimsy,
label: Paragraph

text: ugly, characterless objects produced by indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial methods. Morris considered the machine
label: Paragraph

text: inappropriate tor producing objects intended
label: Title

text: for everyday use. Such objects should be
label: Paragraph

text: reserved for handiwork, so that the quality of
label: Paragraph

text: products and of work might be re-established.
label: Paragraph

text: The Werkbund took up this protest against an
label: Paragraph

text: environment lacking in quality, but its founders
label: Paragraph

text: - Hermann *Muthesius, Fritz Schumacher and
label: Caption

text: Peter *Behrens ~ saw in the machine an
label: Title

text: improved tool which must, and could, be used
label: Paragraph

text: to ensure that its products were also of high
label: Paragraph

text: quality. The Werkbund took as a starting point
label: Paragraph

text: the idea that industrial development could not
label: Paragraph

text: be reversed.
label: Paragraph

text: Their efforts had a strong echo immediately,
label: Paragraph

text: and the effect of their movement extended
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the cultivated middle classes who
label: Paragraph

text: suffered from the general lack of culture during
label: Paragraph

text: this period. Industrialists and businessmen rec-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: products could afford. In the very year of the
label: Paragraph
